meta.article_title: January 20, 2025 - Practice Each Aspect of a Technique Separately

january_20_2025_practice_each_aspect_tec.probleme: Trying to learn all parts of a technique at once
causes_communes: Simultaneously working on stroke, contact, timing, footwork, positioning, and spin reading
Jumping to random/live drills before isolating components

debutant: Break a technique into parts and learn each in sequence (e.g., start backhand flip vs simple short backspin).
intermediaire: Add variations stepwise: heavy backspin, no-spin, sidespin, side-topspin; then mixed spins where you don't know what's coming.
avance: After component mastery, do random drills that force adjustment between forehand/backhand and varied incoming balls.

erreurs_a_eviter: Learning multiple sub-skills simultaneously without isolation
Skipping targeted fixes (e.g., ready position, two-foot movement, grip) before combining

meta.article_title: January 13, 2025 - Why Lobbing is Good For You, Why Lobbing is Bad For You

causes_communes: Using lobs as a default even when a stronger attacking/controlling option exists
Backing up from the table too easily

debutant: Recognize benefits: save lost points; practice off-table footwork; build topspin touch; reaction training; useful vs some opponents; enjoyable.
intermediaire: Avoid bad habits: don’t lob when a more effective, less defensive shot is available; resist backing up unnecessarily.
avance: Use lobbing selectively for tactics, practice value, and variety while maintaining a primary close-to-table game plan.

erreurs_a_eviter: Defaulting to lobbing instead of higher-percentage offensive or control options

meta.article_title: January 6, 2025 - Blocking is Just Reverse Dodgeball

january_6_2025_blocking_reverse_dodgebal.probleme: Unstable blocks from reaching instead of moving
january_6_2025_blocking_reverse_dodgebal.diagnostic: Players reach and contort rather than step to put the body behind the ball.
causes_communes: Relying on arm reach rather than footwork
Trying to block from the side of the body instead of in front

debutant: On backhand blocks, step to intercept the ball with the torso’s centerline; hold racket out to meet the ball in front.
intermediaire: Adopt the same body-behind-ball concept on forehand blocks (right side area for right-handers).
avance: Minimize reaching except as last resort; make stepping into the ball the default for repeatable blocking.

erreurs_a_eviter: Reaching for blocks without moving the feet
Letting the ball drift outside the body line

december_30_2024_experiment_and_learn.probleme: Stagnating by only refining existing strengths
december_30_2024_experiment_and_learn.diagnostic: Lack of experimentation limits discovery of new effective tactics and skills.
causes_communes: Focusing practice solely on repetition of known patterns
Avoiding trial of new serves, receives, placements, and pace changes

debutant: In each playing session, try at least one new variation (serve/receive/placement/tempo).
intermediaire: Identify opponent-specific discoveries (e.g., dead-block to middle causing soft returns) and add them to your toolkit.
avance: Balance drill repetition for mastery with targeted in-game experimentation to expand options.

erreurs_a_eviter: Spending most sessions experimenting at the expense of core skill reps
Refusing to try new patterns in game situations

meta.article_title: December 23, 2024 – Are You Maximizing Your Service Spin?

december_23_2024_maximizing_your_service.probleme: Practicing serves without maximizing spin production
december_23_2024_maximizing_your_service.diagnostic: Low effort with limited acceleration leads to weak spin.
causes_communes: Serving for control only
Insufficient racket acceleration and fine graze

debutant: Practice with intent to maximize racket speed and grazing contact to create heavy spin.
intermediaire: Sustain physical effort during serve practice; learn to control high-spin contact through repetition.
avance: Use maximum spin practice to turn spin serves into major weapons; only fake spin when intentionally serving no-spin.

meta.article_title: December 16, 2024 - What Type of Backhand Flip Should You Develop?

december_16_2024_backhand_flip_type_to_d.probleme: Choosing a backhand flip style for short receive
causes_communes: Lack of a reliable backhand flip option on serve receive
Assuming banana flip is mandatory without practice investment

debutant: Develop a basic backhand flip (light topspin/drive) focusing on depth and placement, especially versus underspin.
intermediaire: If aiming higher, practice the banana backhand flip (mini-loop over table with topspin/sidespin).
avance: Choose based on commitment and physical comfort; older players may prefer the simpler flip if banana flip stresses the arm.

erreurs_a_eviter: Skipping a flip entirely on short balls
Forcing banana flip without adequate practice base

december_9_2024_off_speed_blocks.probleme: Over-hitting against opponents positioned off the table
december_9_2024_off_speed_blocks.diagnostic: Repeatedly giving the opponent the pace they are set for while lowering your own consistency.
causes_communes: Habit of hitting hard every ball
Not using pace variation as a tactical tool

debutant: Mix in soft blocks to throw off timing and catch the opponent out of position.
intermediaire: Use soft block to set up the next attack (pound-pat-POUND pattern); employ chop or sidespin blocks on backhand.
avance: Deceive with occasional soft forehand blocks from a strong-side setup to create easier next-ball attacks.

december_2_2024_where_to_serve_from.probleme: Predictable serve location (always from backhand corner)
december_2_2024_where_to_serve_from.diagnostic: Opponents get comfortable when you serve from the same spot repeatedly.
causes_communes: Habit of serving only from backhand side to stay in position

debutant: Add serves from the middle and forehand side to increase discomfort and errors.
intermediaire: From forehand side, serve both short and long to both wings with same motion; exploit awkward short-forehand receive.
avance: Follow-through from FH-side serves back toward backhand to cover deep returns; use FH-side serving to set up dominant backhand if that’s your strength.

erreurs_a_eviter: Letting opponents adjust to a single serving location

meta.article_title: November 25, 2024 - How to Do a Relentless Three-Point Attack

november_25_2024_relentless_three_point_.probleme: Difficulty sustaining attacks across all three targets
november_25_2024_relentless_three_point_.diagnostic: Breakdown in placement choices, recovery/positioning, or balance after first attack.
causes_communes: Attacking into lines that leave open counters you can’t cover
Finishing shots off-balance so recovery is slow

debutant: Use PPB: Placement to wide FH, wide BH, and middle; favor middle and weaker side while anticipating likely returns.
intermediaire: Integrate positioning into your follow-through so you’re already moving back into place after each attack.
avance: Maintain balance (weight between feet) through swings to enable instant movement for the next ball.

erreurs_a_eviter: Going down the line from BH corner without the speed to cover the open forehand
Stopping after a shot instead of recovering during follow-through

meta.article_title: November 18, 2024 - How to Loop Against Deep, Heavy Backspin

november_18_2024_loop_against_deep_heavy.probleme: Struggling to loop deep, heavy backspin
november_18_2024_loop_against_deep_heavy.diagnostic: Incorrect racket/stroke angle or insufficient power; unfamiliarity with required lift.
causes_communes: Using angles/strokes tuned for lighter backspin
Not bending knees or dropping shoulder to lift
Relying on power method without the athletic base

debutant: Use the lift method: lower racket with open angle, bend knees (esp. back leg), drop playing shoulder, and drive up with emphasis on upward arc.
intermediaire: If still netting, lift even more and aim to arc long; convert incoming backspin to heavy topspin.
avance: Power (Chinese-style) option: sink ball into sponge and drive forward/up with high power—requires athleticism and often harder sponge; if knees limit, favor slow, spinny lift.

erreurs_a_eviter: Forcing power loops without physical capacity
